At first glance this game seems to shine with depth and complexity. Each card in the deck that you build has its own statistics and unique abilities that come into play during your turn. The only problem is that once you pick your deck and choose to go against an opponent you can't do anything other than sit back and watch as the game plays itself. The outcome of the match is entirely in the hands of the AI that chooses which card on the opposite side is going to get hit with your attack or is going to be affected by your creature's ability. Basically you're at the mercy of rng and more often than not you end up losing the match due to AI's poor decisions. It's especially apparent later on in the game where every turn matters and you have to pray for the computer to choose to attack the right enemy this time around so you can break out from the endless cycle of hitting the rematch button.

Once the novelty of the game wears off and frustration sets in you'll start noticing all the flaws this game has and stop having fun.

I got to the 8th chapter of the campaign before I decided I finally had enough with AI's mistakes. It honestly started to feel like Groundhog Day.

The only thing this game has going for it is its lewd artwork.

An interesting collectable card game with some unusual gameplay mechanics, Epic Card Battles is not a traditional trading card game or collecting card game, and it's roots as a freeware mobile game are blatantly obvious, from the numerous microtransactions built into the gameplay to the fact zooming into the art of individual cards turn them sideways, making it essentially pointless on a desktop computer. reviewText:
After seeing all the negative reviews for this game and deciding to give it a try anyway, I'm genuinely surprised at how much fun I've had with it.

The somewhat awkwardly-titled Epic Cards Battle is a CCG (card collection game) where you build a small (up to 6 card) hand of cards from your collection to do battle against your opponent. Without going into too much detail, each card can be one of three types; Creature, Spell or Triggered. Your creatures battle your opponent's creatures directly, and also serve as your life-blood - ie. you win by eliminating all your oponents creature cards. Spell cards provide a wide variety of effects such as buffs, debuffs or direct damage-dealing, while Triggered cards are similar in effect to spell cards, but will only activate under specific circumstances. The actual battles themselves are completely non-interactive, but don't be fooled; in campaign mode at least, selecting the right cards for each challenge increasingly involves strategy and careful forethought - something which caught me by surprise having played a few CCGs on mobile which are largely devoid of any real gameplay.

During the 18.5 hours total I've spent playing this game at the time of writing this review, I've completely ignored the cash-shop and PvP elements, instead focusing on campaign mode, daily rewards, and shop items that can be bought with in-game earnings. This is honestly enough. All up, there's probably a good 10-15 solid hours worth of gameplay to be had from campaign mode before you'll hit a difficulty wall, and will have a hard time progressing further without a more fleshed out collection. From there, you'll find yourself logging in for short sessions, mostly to recieve daily rewards, doing a spot of enchanting/combining, and playing maybe a round or two here and there; things I've still found to be satisfying in their own way.

For the type of game this is, I've found the quality of art on the cards to be a little diasppointing - not bad, but not that great either. Even the 4-5 star cash-shop cards are largely so-so (devs, if you are reading this, commission high-caliber fantasy/ecchi artists to do art on the cards you're expecting people to pay for - they'll sell a lot better).

Having said that though, I'd definitely recommend campaign mode to any strategy/card/table-top game fans. I can't speak for the competitive side of it, but there is a lot of fun to be had from the free elements alone.

-------------------

UPDATE: Turns out the number of daily rewards is finite. Now that I've claimed them all, it doesn't really feel like there's anything worth logging in for without paying money - which given the quality vs price-point of the paid content, I'm just not enticed to do. Bit of a disappointing end, but I'd still recommend the game.

reviewText:
First a disclosure, I am mainly leaving this review to the free gems. Normally would not leave a review as in my eye this game is neither good or bad enough to merit one. Honestly the game is a hair further in the bad category so that is why it does not have my recommendation. In the vein of being helpful here is a quick pro/con as I have seen in the game.

Cons:
1) The free packs and random cards are not that good. The packs you purchase with in game gold rarely give you anything good. Mostly get a lot of 1-2 star cards. The packs which claim to give better drops cost a special currency which is really hard to come by in game, but can be bought via cold hard cash.
2) Mission rewards seem a bit lackluster. To get the better rewards for missions you mainly need a specialized set up requiring certain cards. To get the cards you need to do missions... which require a specilaized set up. Depending on rng you can find yourself in an unfun situation of just grinding away. Also, red gems are hard to come by and you need a goodly amount of them to level cards to make them better.
3) Limits on how much you can play and ineffecient energy system. Everytime you complete a mission or do something it drains your energy. You get a certain amount of energy a day, and it can be replenished by leveling up. The starting missions cost very little energy to complete, and you level up quickly. The issue is that you hit the cap of your energy and you never receive a lot of energy you get by leveling. EDIT: It appears the energy replenishes faster than I first assumed. This alleviates most of the issue. I understand it prevents people from exploiting things, but if you bing out and play it can prevent you from doing thing you want to.
4) Basic features are purchaseable via in game gold. Things like being able to view your match after you finish and speeding up the matches are purchaseable.
5) The farming feature to go back and reap rewards from earlier levels is not really worth it. You only get 20 or so gold and expend a significant chunk of energy. No way to get red gems other than completing quests.
6) Hints are really not that useful if you do not have the cards. In the 3-4 cases I have used all I got was 6 sets which all included the same 2-3 cards in different orderings. Also, doing what the hint suggests does not always give you victory, there is still a fair amount of rng at play.

Pros:
1) Game plays itself. Been playing this on one computer while playing skyrim on another. Gives me something to do during loading screens.
2) Card art and music is nice.
3) Solid rock/paper/scissors mechanics.
4) Good solid time waster to play while your doing other things

The game has a good base. And my complaints can be solved if the developers do the following things:
1) First time through the campaign missions costs no energy.
2) Implementation of an energy bank. Something that your spare energy that you get by leveling up goes to so it is not wasted.
3) Better drops in the non-gem packs. At least always give us a 3 star. Have the 1 or 5 random card have much higher odds of giving you but no guaranteed 3 star. While the booster pack randomness stays the same but guarantees you a 3 star.
4) Easier way to get red and blue gems. More repeatable missions to gain them that do not drain your energy so much. Perhaps a mission that when you play it gives you energy. That way you are always able to play if you want.

I hope my feed back helps.

reviewText:
A card game where you build a deck of 6 cards and compete against other players. There's also a campaign mode that tests your wit depending on what cards you have in your collection. There are 3 types of cards, unit, spells and triggers. Units have HP, attack damage and defense points. Spells are auto-casted when the spell is ready. Triggers are like spells but they will casted when a condition is meet. Cards have 5 levels of rarity (ascending rarity: silver, gold, diamond, legend and epic) and 5 races/legions (a legion is strong against 1 legion while weak against another). (as of today, they have a total of 145 cards with one more yet to be released for this update). There are various currencies in the game: Energy (allows you to play), rubies (allows you to level up your cards), diamonds (can purchase a lot of stuff in game, including other currencies), gold (purchase fewer things than diamonds). New cards are released every update.

There are micro-transactions in the game, which will make the game easier. Free players can NOT get epic(highest)  rarity cards but there are only SLIGHTLY more powerful than normal cards.

Pros:
- cards are very well drawn
- simple casual game play
- good UI

Cons:
- free 2 play players will hit a glass ceiling. Playing against P2P will require luck and/or experience.
- cards can be expensive

Overall a good game, it does what it promises.

===Disclaimer===

There's a promotion going on that offers rewards for Steam reviews (good or bad).  I’m not bothering to take them up on it, though, since I’m more interested in puzzling through the campaign than acquiring powerful cards.  Too much power would make the puzzling too easy.


===Short Version===

Don't expect a normal TCG.  All the strategy is frontloaded into deckbuilding, so instead of a frontline commander making small tactical decisions, you’re the general planning the battle on a map in his tent.

The single-player campaign is a puzzle-TCG hybrid, since you see the enemy's deck in advance and build one to counter it.  Each card has its own deterministic targeting strategy, so if you think it through you can choose how BOTH sides will attack.

The big issue is complexity.  MtG creatures have three stats that consistently matter (Power, Toughness, and mana cost).  ECB units have seven, so there's a lot to track when running battles in your head.  Overall I prefer traditional TCGs, but it's an interesting, if brain-tiring, twist on the genre.

reviewText:
I'm rather astounded by the negative reviews for this game.
Personally I found it to be one of the few TCGs on Steam that have kept my attention for a decent amount of time.
It's got great content as far as I'm concerned, it's very unlike the other titles.

Noteable features over other~

* Great linear progression - Introduction to different features isn't shown until unlocked, but core content is covered. You can enhance cards, level your character, etc.

* Superior strategy and planning - Each campaign level requires you to analyze the enemy's deck, sort through your own, and then cross your fingers that the monsters, abilities, and supporting spells you've chosen are a working strategy against your opponent.

* Quality over quantity - Each match is fairly fast-paced and the number of cards used per battle is 6 [unless I'm mistaken]
* The individual card's abilties are ridiculously unique, and each card in your deck is useful for a different situation
based on its specific capabilities and stats.

* Unique and quality artwork - None of the artwork or UI is reused or stolen from other games. The style is particularly detailed and gorgeous in my opinion. It's a great moderation between some of the other examples that are too cartoonish or hardcore. There is great variety, and another aspect of note is that portraits of women characters are anatomically correct. Fan servicing is tastefully so, and it's realistic anatomically correct and variable.

* Fast load, solid UI, stable framerate, no noteable bugs, stable build.

--- Overall I think it's a great side-game that's fun to play for decent periods of time. It's a solid competitor against the alternatives, and I highly recommend at least trying it. I can only hope y'all enjoy as it as much as I have!

reviewText:
tl:dr version:

- You can get all the cards if you grind, or pay to get them sooner.
- It isn't about actually playing your cards in a match, but rather about selecting the best ones for battle.

Long version:

This is indeed one of those games where you can obtain higher end cards by spending cash, or you can complete daily challenges to earn rewards to gather them up, or try to craft them from lower tier cards to higher. Just like about every other card game out there, even mighty Hearthstone.

One thing that is vastly different about this game, is that you don't actually play the cards in the match. The strategic focus instead is being familair with your cards and selecting the best ones for the task, then the game simulates the results. The cards deal in ranges - such as dealing 100 to 200 damage, so there is some random number generation aspects, that when combined with weaknesses and skills can actually create a pretty diverse approach.

Matchmaking is some of the best. When I started playing Hearthstone, I could find myself getting stomped on in PVP play by someone who had rare cards that were only available in their Solo Adventure expansions. A brutal learning experience. Here, I have no card presently better than 3 stars (it goes up to 5 stars I believe), and in over 25 pvp matches, I've only faced two people who even fielded a 4 star card, and I won 1 and lost 1. That to me is pretty fair for matchmaking.

It also gets props for being pretty intense, as like old school Magic the Gathering, you can actually have matches that wager cards used.

Pros:
- Solid campaign play compared to a lot of the other card games, with three different difficulty levels for the missions and those missions collected in different chapters (at least three chapters, as that's how far I'm at this point)
- In game public, guild, or campaign chat
- Nice artwork
- Good matchmaking
- Pro format is interesting with two cards at a time selection between seeing what your opponent has, adds more strategy as you adjust.

Cons:
- User Interface is a little odd at times in trying to figure out where you're at.
- Somethings are well explained while others aren't,  such as evolving cards
- If you have a run of bad luck, you can see your energy depleted, which apparently ends your ability to play, which is dissappointing. I've not run out of energy during a play session, but I've come close after getting used to the pro matches.

reviewText:
This is a game of two sides of the same coin.

On one hand you have brilliant art and music. There are also mechanics that make you think tactically in devising a good deck of cards. I do admit that the campaign is fun and somewhat addictive after you have gotten used to how the game works also. Epic Cards Battle also has a very informative introduction, if you're able to absorb written information like a big, dry sponge. Additionally, for any information you might have skipped over, you can easily refer back to any of it, and more, via the in-game library. But that's where the good points end.

The first thing you'll notice is the anime-esque artwork showing off huge breasts like they're zoo attractions. It may bug you. The next thing you'll notice is this is not a TCG. There is no trading involved whatsoever. CG. But you carry on anyway, because it's fun after the first five minutes.
Eventually, if you follow the single player campaign, you'll come across some missions you, as a free player at least, will struggle greatly in as in order to 3-star the mission, you require either rare cards leveled to ridiculous amounts or those you can pay for. While you can use the in-game coins you get (somewhat easily) to buy new packs of cards, those randomised packs will give you so many of the same more common cards that you probably will never see one that made the menial process worth it.

Once you've had enough of that you can play against players in a system that has no visible matchmaking rules in place. You'll find yourself going against players who have some of the best cards in the game. Not only that but while you may have struggled to find that one great card you can get from the free packs, these players will have two or three of them, plus other more elusive ones. It is true that you can upgrade your cards by enhancing or via evolution which is necessary to combat these pay-to-win players but it's still a lengthy process that rapidly transfers to a grind.

As for recommending this game, I still do. It's worth five minutes here and there by having on your phone for while you're out and about, but that's about as far as it goes. Sooner or later, you'll arrive at a strut where you have no coins, unable to get more, and you don't have the right cards. You queue to play against players and find you can't win because they have the best cards money can buy.

This is a game that uses RNG like no other and a P2W system like no other. It's okay for a free game, but that's it. You're better off with Magic. This game should definitely give you more of a reward for logging in daily. I would rather listen to my girlfriend moan than play this for long amounts of time.
